newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Soaring turnover on Hungary's BCE seen continuing.
newsitem.headline: Soaring turnover on Hungary's BCE seen continuing.

text.p: January to August turnover on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) has reached a record 456.7 billion forints, a BCE official said on Tuesday.
"This figure is twice the turnover of the first six years," BCE spokesman Attila Lovas told Reuters.
BCE trading started late 1989, and he said turnover for 1989 and 1990 was 574 million forints. The BCE does not have separate figures for each of those years.
Total turnover for 1996 is expected to be around 600 billion forints, he said.
Of the BCE's three sections, financials account for the bulk of total turnover.

The BCE's financial section offers futures contracts for seven currencies and three-month deposit interest rates. On September 19, the BCE will add one- and three-month Budapest Interbank Offered Rate (BUBOR) futures.

The BCE's two other sections trades traditional commodity goods. Grains this year traded 30 percent of Hungary's grain production, while the livestock section is expected to double its turnover this year, the BCE said.
